1he following !, copy Of letter addressed 10
Mr.. HARDING, President Of the jefferson Debating
Society OF bingham. Mass. by The LATE Mr.. JFs.
SERsos, on receiving information Of its institution


MONTICELLO. April go, 1924.


SIR,-I have daily received your ayor Of the 9th
INST informing me Of the institution Of a Debating
Society in bingham, composed Of adheren,s TO The
republican principles OF the revolution and / am
Justly sensible Of the honor done my name by as.
sociating it with the title Of the Society. The OBJ
jeet Of the institution 10 audsble and in repobli
can nation, whose citizens are TO be led by reason
and persu aston, not by force, the art Of reasoning
becomes OF the FIRST importance. In this line an
siquiiy has left US the finest models for imitation,
and he who s,udea and initiate. them most ne arly
Will nearest approach the perfection oil the art
Among theae should consider the speeches Of
Livy, Sallust and Iacitus pre- eminent specimens
OF logic, taste, and that asnsentious breyity which
using not word TO spare, leaves not momen, for
inatten,ion 10 The hearer. AmpN6caion 10 the vice
of modern oratory. h is an insult to an assembly
Cf reasonable men, disgusting and revolving instead
OF persuading. Speeches measured By the hour
die with the hour. will not, however, further in
dulge The disposition OF age to sermonize, and espe.
cialy TO these surrounded by so much better advice
With my apologies, therefore, for hszarding even
these observations, and my prayers for the success
at your institution, be pleased TO accept, for the SO.
ciey and yourself, the assurances OF my high con-
sseralisn TIL: JEFFERSON.

PORTUGAL.


During the year 1892 thirteen Portuguese slave
ships having on board upwards Of 100 slaves, we're
condemned at Sierra Leone, for trading in slaves
north of the line. Some Of the cases involved per-
iures without end, and atrocities OF the most out
rageous and revolving kind and implicated IN the
guilt attending them Portuguese funcionaries on
the coast Of Africa OF the very highest class and
all of lhe cases afforded proofs OF The most repre-
hensible disregard ON the part OF The Brazilian au
ihorties, Of the stipuatons OF the treaties with this
country. The Iicenses granted to these ships per
mitted them, while their destination was declared to
be Africa south o the line, 10 visit ST. Thomas's,
Cameroons, Calsbar, sc. which no motive could be
assigned for their visiting, but that of carrying on
an Illicit slave trade. Nay, the authorities in Brazil
appear to have concurred with the contrabandists,
in giving fictitious names to places north OF the line
borrowed from places south Of the line, for the pur
pose ofdeceiYing the British cruzer. and the mixed
commission courts. The name Of Molembo, q
place south Of the line, 10 which The Portuguese
slave trade is still permitted has been transferred
for this proagate purpose, to place near Onim, in
she Blight Of Benin.


In the case OF one vessel the Condo de Villa Flor
taken with l12 slave. on board, 1t was fully proved,
that the governor Of Bissao was himself an inte
rested participalor in the Illegal embaikation o
slaves, certain number Of the slaves being his
property; some 0! them being catered in the me
moranda as shipped and received from his official
residence as if all decency was cast of from the gov
eminent of the settlement Such is the ,tong, but
IN nj he uAu 0f hf mi xrf
commission court The examinations in the case
develop the most complicated TISSUE OF fraudulent
expf dents Tor defeating the end. OF justice among
shem, fabricated log books, exhibiting voyage from
the Brazla 10 Cabenda, by way o, The Cape de
Verbs, when The real destination was Blssao; and
schedules pointing out the brbes by which the con
niyance OF the Judge. governor, &c. "M to be Sc
cured at the port OF discharge in the Braz,ls. This
vessel had already made several very successful and
ganful voyages under the shelter OF these ingenious
expedients The owner, in one Of his letters, de
clared his Intention Of putting end, by this voyage
70 his course OF slave trading, as, "prosded," he
says, +" that it were the pleasure Of the Almighty
that every thing should be placed in safety, the y
would have reaped good harvest" In consequence.
i may be presumed OF his capture this oc ason,
which prevented his gathering the lruits he had an
icpated, he appears, by the Sierra Leone Gazette.
10 have returned to the in the succeeding year,
snd to have successfully effected another voyage.


The directors will give the particulars Of only one
other case


The Portuguese schooner boat, San Jose MALAGA,
belonging 10 lady Of Princes Island, the daughter
Of Gomez, formerly the Governor AVID still mem
Der of the governing una OF tina, island, though
only OF the burden OF seven tors, was sent to Gala
bar for slaves Thirty slaves we're purchased, and
having been put on board the boat, il made .aii ior
Princes Island. But The voyage proved tedious
provisions bsgan 10 fail, and the allowance of ood
was reduced TO yam daily for two slaves At last
the provisions snd wafer wholly failed Ten slave
persisted and the whole must have shared their
Fate had not the vessel got back 10 Calabar after
having been Six weeks al sea. The surviving slave,
we're 10 she most deploraole state Of emaciator
nd wretchednes.. Nor was this 10 be wondered a
sor besides their prisason,. they were manaeled
together, and cooped up in vessel Ct only seven
tons burden; having no shelter but what could ne
afforded by the space between The water casks anc
the deck, space Of seven inches


In the year 1922, i, appears that % ,246 slave
we're imported into Rio de Jareiro alone, from III,
coast OF Africa. The number embarked had beer
3l,240.-3 484 having died on the passage. In on
vessel, containing 492 slaves, l94 had died in an
other. containing 63l,-2l3 had died in a ,hird
containing Ala Ans had died &c. &c.


The number imported into Bahia, in the sam
gear, waa upwards Of 5000

From NE n Z. Commercial .4drerfiser, Feb. 9.

GEORGIA AND THE EINDIANS.-Thisc con-
troversy, which has SO long agtated the country
now lowering like cloud black with the brewing
sorm,o and again vanishing into thin air, has SUD


denly burst upon us with the impetuosiiy OF wnlri


wind. We publish to-day the documents referred
to In the Presidents Message published yesterday
and The debate on the subject in the Senate. nc
course pursued BY The President on this occasion
is we conceive the proper one, and we have no douo
il will meet the spproba.ion of the American people
generally Its precisely the course we long since


md repeatedly, said was the only one which couio
be pursued, if Georgia persisted in her illJudget
measures. A part Of the people OF Georgia VIII
perhaps, declam loudly against the Executive
their interest or rather hope o gain, Tor they nave
never invested one cent purchased an interest ~
any manner whatever, in the Creek lands,-Deins
directly involved. That our readers may unoer-
stand the merits of he we VIII give pfiel MS
tory OF the affair. The treaty OF the Indian springs
(Which was anaulled by the treaty OF Washington
ceded 10 the United States for the use oil Georgia
all the lands lying within the state OF Georgia be
longing 10 the Creeks and before that treaty was
annulled, the Legislature Of Georgia passed la"
authorizing the Governor to cause those lands TO DC
surveyed and distributed by lottery among the peo
pie OF fGeorgia.-The treaty oi the Indian springs
heweyer was proved to have been obtained Dy un


lair means, and new one was concluded at w ash
ington last winter, abrogating the torn'er cstao-


shing the lines oil the lands which the Creeks oy u
ceded to the United States for the use OF Georgia
and binding the United States to protect the Indians
in the possession ot the lands retained by them.


A small strip OF the Creek lands, il appears, with


in the limits Of Geotgia, and which was ceded by
The treaty Of the Indian Springs, is not included 10
the lines of the new treaty. But even Georgia is
not cerain that these lands lie within her limits
for the line between her and Alabama is not esab-
lshed, and un il is, she does no know but that
this same land may lie within the limits OF Alabama
Governor Troup. has oil along refused 10 acknow.


cdgs the new treaty, and recently ordefed his sur
seyors 10 proceed and survey the lands acquired
{, orr the Greeks BY The new treaty, and also he
strip mentioned above. Those engaged in the sur
yev Of tho latter portion were stopped and deprived
Of their instruments by the Indians, as stated in The
Ps,ro. several days since, and IT IS ior this act and
against these survey that the President has nsti


tuted the proceedings II II be admitted that trea
ties are pat, Of the "supreme law Of the land,
and that ,he powers tina, can make, can sbrogste
hem and il il be admitted, that, the President o.
the United States is bound by duty the people, and
hi, oath OF Office. TO see that the laws executed
then is The Executive justified in arfesng and pun
ishing the vioa,ors Of these laws, whoever they are
and however elevated they may be- IN heir own
tmalon or that oil the world. We do net helie,e
that any thing serious will grow out ot the al


lair than personal punishment Of the individuals VIC
lsilng tho law. Ii is in vain, that the Members from
Georgia endea,or TO make the controversy one be
iween the General Government and the S ate q
Georeia-No 10 person can be recognized by the Gen
eral Government in the affair, excep, IN his indyid
ual capacity Governor Ttoup himself, only 3.
known i found violating he treaty, as George nj
Troup citizen oil Georgia Patriot.
Baltimore, February7.

The Communication Of the President TO Congress
upon The subject OF the differences between the Gen
ers Government and the State OF Georgia. growing
out OF the treaty with the Creek Indians, and The
proceedings which took place in Congress in rela
tion TO i, will be read with the deepest interest
and with corresponding feeling Of teeret that tht
rash counsrls OF Governor Troup and his factor
should have produced such state oil things as nov
exists. AID have rendered recessary the energetic
language with which the communication OF the Ex
ecutiye concludes. Baltimore american,

full articles.headline: From the bingham Gazette.
full articles.article:
1he following !, copy Of letter addressed 10
Mr.. HARDING, President Of the jefferson Debating
Society OF bingham. Mass. by The LATE Mr.. JFs.
SERsos, on receiving information Of its institution


MONTICELLO. April go, 1924.


SIR,-I have daily received your ayor Of the 9th
INST informing me Of the institution Of a Debating
Society in bingham, composed Of adheren,s TO The
republican principles OF the revolution and / am
Justly sensible Of the honor done my name by as.
sociating it with the title Of the Society. The OBJ
jeet Of the institution 10 audsble and in repobli
can nation, whose citizens are TO be led by reason
and persu aston, not by force, the art Of reasoning
becomes OF the FIRST importance. In this line an
siquiiy has left US the finest models for imitation,
and he who s,udea and initiate. them most ne arly
Will nearest approach the perfection oil the art
Among theae should consider the speeches Of
Livy, Sallust and Iacitus pre- eminent specimens
OF logic, taste, and that asnsentious breyity which
using not word TO spare, leaves not momen, for
inatten,ion 10 The hearer. AmpN6caion 10 the vice
of modern oratory. h is an insult to an assembly
Cf reasonable men, disgusting and revolving instead
OF persuading. Speeches measured By the hour
die with the hour. will not, however, further in
dulge The disposition OF age to sermonize, and espe.
cialy TO these surrounded by so much better advice
With my apologies, therefore, for hszarding even
these observations, and my prayers for the success
at your institution, be pleased TO accept, for the SO.
ciey and yourself, the assurances OF my high con-
sseralisn TIL: JEFFERSON.

lowing his brgs and schooncrs to cruise on The coast
while ne himself engages the whole attention
OF the Spanish feet Of 4 frigatcs and briggs A

From the eighteenth and nineteenth reports Of the

May, 1925.


PORTUGAL.


During the year 1892 thirteen Portuguese slave
ships having on board upwards Of 100 slaves, we're
condemned at Sierra Leone, for trading in slaves
north of the line. Some Of the cases involved per-
iures without end, and atrocities OF the most out
rageous and revolving kind and implicated IN the
guilt attending them Portuguese funcionaries on
the coast Of Africa OF the very highest class and
all of lhe cases afforded proofs OF The most repre-
hensible disregard ON the part OF The Brazilian au
ihorties, Of the stipuatons OF the treaties with this
country. The Iicenses granted to these ships per
mitted them, while their destination was declared to
be Africa south o the line, 10 visit ST. Thomas's,
Cameroons, Calsbar, sc. which no motive could be
assigned for their visiting, but that of carrying on
an Illicit slave trade. Nay, the authorities in Brazil
appear to have concurred with the contrabandists,
in giving fictitious names to places north OF the line
borrowed from places south Of the line, for the pur
pose ofdeceiYing the British cruzer. and the mixed
commission courts. The name Of Molembo, q
place south Of the line, 10 which The Portuguese
slave trade is still permitted has been transferred
for this proagate purpose, to place near Onim, in
she Blight Of Benin.


In the case OF one vessel the Condo de Villa Flor
taken with l12 slave. on board, 1t was fully proved,
that the governor Of Bissao was himself an inte
rested participalor in the Illegal embaikation o
slaves, certain number Of the slaves being his
property; some 0! them being catered in the me
moranda as shipped and received from his official
residence as if all decency was cast of from the gov
eminent of the settlement Such is the ,tong, but
IN nj he uAu 0f hf mi xrf
commission court The examinations in the case
develop the most complicated TISSUE OF fraudulent
expf dents Tor defeating the end. OF justice among
shem, fabricated log books, exhibiting voyage from
the Brazla 10 Cabenda, by way o, The Cape de
Verbs, when The real destination was Blssao; and
schedules pointing out the brbes by which the con
niyance OF the Judge. governor, &c. "M to be Sc
cured at the port OF discharge in the Braz,ls. This
vessel had already made several very successful and
ganful voyages under the shelter OF these ingenious
expedients The owner, in one Of his letters, de
clared his Intention Of putting end, by this voyage
70 his course OF slave trading, as, "prosded," he
says, +" that it were the pleasure Of the Almighty
that every thing should be placed in safety, the y
would have reaped good harvest" In consequence.
i may be presumed OF his capture this oc ason,
which prevented his gathering the lruits he had an
icpated, he appears, by the Sierra Leone Gazette.
10 have returned to the in the succeeding year,
snd to have successfully effected another voyage.


The directors will give the particulars Of only one
other case


The Portuguese schooner boat, San Jose MALAGA,
belonging 10 lady Of Princes Island, the daughter
Of Gomez, formerly the Governor AVID still mem
Der of the governing una OF tina, island, though
only OF the burden OF seven tors, was sent to Gala
bar for slaves Thirty slaves we're purchased, and
having been put on board the boat, il made .aii ior
Princes Island. But The voyage proved tedious
provisions bsgan 10 fail, and the allowance of ood
was reduced TO yam daily for two slaves At last
the provisions snd wafer wholly failed Ten slave
persisted and the whole must have shared their
Fate had not the vessel got back 10 Calabar after
having been Six weeks al sea. The surviving slave,
we're 10 she most deploraole state Of emaciator
nd wretchednes.. Nor was this 10 be wondered a
sor besides their prisason,. they were manaeled
together, and cooped up in vessel Ct only seven
tons burden; having no shelter but what could ne
afforded by the space between The water casks anc
the deck, space Of seven inches


In the year 1922, i, appears that % ,246 slave
we're imported into Rio de Jareiro alone, from III,
coast OF Africa. The number embarked had beer
3l,240.-3 484 having died on the passage. In on
vessel, containing 492 slaves, l94 had died in an
other. containing 63l,-2l3 had died in a ,hird
containing Ala Ans had died &c. &c.


The number imported into Bahia, in the sam
gear, waa upwards Of 5000

From The ~ Z. Commercial .9drerfiser, Feb. 9.


DEATH IF the Empress of BroSit.- brig IIora
ito, Capt. Hall, has arrived from, Rio Jsneiro and
brings intelligence that the Empress Of Brazil died
on the 10Th Of December. The Emperor was a, Rio
Grand about the LIST Of December, on his wsy 10
Monevldeo, with about 5000 men the squadron has
gone round. Com. Brown has taken, off Santos, a
Brazilian corvette, OF % guns; and it was reported,
and ally believed he had had an action with the
Brazilian iigste Amazon, the latter end OF Noyem-
ber. and that the Amazon had been much injured
Com. Brown was in corvette cruising on the Bra
zlian coast. The Macedonian frigse remained a,
Rio Janeiro The Boston, sloop oi war Tor Santos,
and the Cyane for the River Plate, sailed early II
December The Holy which lately arrived, sailed
from Rio Grand Nov cath, at which time the fort
heallons and works for defence were in active pro
gress. AT Monesideo, Flour was 8lo- Pork l6--

full articles.headline: Baltimore, February7.
full articles.article:
GEORGIA AND THE EINDIANS.-Thisc con-
troversy, which has SO long agtated the country
now lowering like cloud black with the brewing
sorm,o and again vanishing into thin air, has SUD


denly burst upon us with the impetuosiiy OF wnlri


wind. We publish to-day the documents referred
to In the Presidents Message published yesterday
and The debate on the subject in the Senate. nc
course pursued BY The President on this occasion
is we conceive the proper one, and we have no douo
il will meet the spproba.ion of the American people
generally Its precisely the course we long since


md repeatedly, said was the only one which couio
be pursued, if Georgia persisted in her illJudget
measures. A part Of the people OF Georgia VIII
perhaps, declam loudly against the Executive
their interest or rather hope o gain, Tor they nave
never invested one cent purchased an interest ~
any manner whatever, in the Creek lands,-Deins
directly involved. That our readers may unoer-
stand the merits of he we VIII give pfiel MS
tory OF the affair. The treaty OF the Indian springs
(Which was anaulled by the treaty OF Washington
ceded 10 the United States for the use oil Georgia
all the lands lying within the state OF Georgia be
longing 10 the Creeks and before that treaty was
annulled, the Legislature Of Georgia passed la"
authorizing the Governor to cause those lands TO DC
surveyed and distributed by lottery among the peo
pie OF fGeorgia.-The treaty oi the Indian springs
heweyer was proved to have been obtained Dy un


lair means, and new one was concluded at w ash
ington last winter, abrogating the torn'er cstao-


shing the lines oil the lands which the Creeks oy u
ceded to the United States for the use OF Georgia
and binding the United States to protect the Indians
in the possession ot the lands retained by them.


A small strip OF the Creek lands, il appears, with


in the limits Of Geotgia, and which was ceded by
The treaty Of the Indian Springs, is not included 10
the lines of the new treaty. But even Georgia is
not cerain that these lands lie within her limits
for the line between her and Alabama is not esab-
lshed, and un il is, she does no know but that
this same land may lie within the limits OF Alabama
Governor Troup. has oil along refused 10 acknow.


cdgs the new treaty, and recently ordefed his sur
seyors 10 proceed and survey the lands acquired
{, orr the Greeks BY The new treaty, and also he
strip mentioned above. Those engaged in the sur
yev Of tho latter portion were stopped and deprived
Of their instruments by the Indians, as stated in The
Ps,ro. several days since, and IT IS ior this act and
against these survey that the President has nsti


tuted the proceedings II II be admitted that trea
ties are pat, Of the "supreme law Of the land,
and that ,he powers tina, can make, can sbrogste
hem and il il be admitted, that, the President o.
the United States is bound by duty the people, and
hi, oath OF Office. TO see that the laws executed
then is The Executive justified in arfesng and pun
ishing the vioa,ors Of these laws, whoever they are
and however elevated they may be- IN heir own
tmalon or that oil the world. We do net helie,e
that any thing serious will grow out ot the al


lair than personal punishment Of the individuals VIC
lsilng tho law. Ii is in vain, that the Members from
Georgia endea,or TO make the controversy one be
iween the General Government and the S ate q
Georeia-No 10 person can be recognized by the Gen
eral Government in the affair, excep, IN his indyid
ual capacity Governor Ttoup himself, only 3.
known i found violating he treaty, as George nj
Troup citizen oil Georgia Patriot.

full articles.headline: THE UNITED STATES AND GEORGIA.
full articles.article:
The Communication Of the President TO Congress
upon The subject OF the differences between the Gen
ers Government and the State OF Georgia. growing
out OF the treaty with the Creek Indians, and The
proceedings which took place in Congress in rela
tion TO i, will be read with the deepest interest
and with corresponding feeling Of teeret that tht
rash counsrls OF Governor Troup and his factor
should have produced such state oil things as nov
exists. AID have rendered recessary the energetic
language with which the communication OF the Ex
ecutiye concludes. Baltimore american,
